readingPart.reading:
adenoidslymph nodethoracic duct
interstitial fluidright lymphatic ductthymus gland
lymph capillariesspleen

questionContent.questionText:
1. collection of stationary lymphatic tissue along lymph vessels [lymph node]

2. large lymphatic vessel that drains lymph from the lower and left side of the body [thoracic duct]

3. organ in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen that destroys worn-out erythrocytes, activates lymphocytes, and stores blood [spleen]

4. mass of lymphatic tissue in the nasopharynx [adenoids]

5. lymphoid organ in the mediastinum that conditions T cells to react to foreign cells in the immune response [thymus gland]

6. tiniest lymphatic vessels [lymph capillaries]

7. large lymphatic vessel in the chest that drains lymph from the upper right part of the body [right lymphatic duct] 

8. fluid in the spaces between cells [interstitial fluid]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms with the descriptions that follow.

readingPart.reading: space between the lungs in the chest
near the aorta in the lumbar area of the body

instructions.instructions: Give the locations of the following lymph nodes.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Cytotoxic T cells are [CD8+ T cells/helper T cells/suppressor T cells] and directly kill foreign cells.

2. Lymphocytes that directly act on antigens are [T cells/B cells/macrophages].

3. CD4 + T cells are [helper T cells/Tregs/B cells] and are deficient in people with AIDS.

4. Lymphocytes that mature into plasma cells and secrete antibodies are [B cells/T cells/macrophages].

5. The type of immunity in which B cells produce antibodies after exposure to antigens is [humoral immunity/natural immunity/cytotoxic immunity].

6. The type of immunity that is the ability to recognize and remember specific antigens and mount an attack on them is [adaptive immunity/natural immunity].

instructions.instructions: Select the correct answer in each sentence.

readingPart.reading:
complement systemhelper T cellplasma cell
dendritic cellmacrophagesuppressor T cell

questionContent.questionText:
1. lymphocyte that matures from a B lymphocyte and secretes antibodies [plasma cell]

2. large phagocyte found in lymph nodes and other tissues of the body [macrophage]

3. CD4 + T cell that aids B cells in recognizing antigens [helper T cell]

4. Treg that inhibits the activity of B and T lymphocytes [suppressor T cell]

5. proteins in the blood that help antibodies and T cells kill their target [complement system]

6. antigen-presenting cell; shows B cells and T cells what to attack [dendritic cell]

instructions.instructions: Match the following cell names with their meanings as given below.

questionContent.questionText:
1. immunoglobulins [Antibodies—IgA, IgE, IgG, IgM, IgD]

2. toxins [Poisons (antigens)]

3. helper T cells [Lymphocytes that aids B cells; CD4 + T cell]

4. suppressor T cells [T lymphocytes that inhibit the activity of B and T cells]

5. cytotoxic T cells [T lymphocytes that directly kill foreign cells (CD8 + T cells)]

6. plasma cells [Transformed B cells that secrete antibodies]

7. interferons and interleukins [Cytokines secreted by cytotoxic T cells]

instructions.instructions: Match the terms with their descriptions in the dropdowns.

questionContent.questionText:
1. removal of the spleen: [splenectomy]

2. enlargement of the spleen: [splenomegaly] 

3. formation of lymph: [lymphopoiesis]

4. tumor of the thymus gland: [thymoma] 

5. inflammation of lymph glands (nodes): [lymphadenitis]

6. deficiency of lymph cells: [lymphocytopenia]

7. pertaining to poison: [toxic]

8. disease of lymph glands (nodes): [lymphadenopathy]

instructions.instructions: Use the given definitions to build medical terms.

readingPart.reading:
AIDSHodgkin lymphomalymphoid organs
allergenhypersplenismthymectomy
anaphylaxislymphedema

questionContent.questionText:
1. syndrome marked by enlargement of the spleen and associated with anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia [hypersplenism]

2. extraordinary hypersensitivity to a foreign protein; marked by hypotension, shock, and respiratory distress [anaphylaxis]

3. antigen capable of causing allergy (hypersensitivity) [allergen]

4. disorder in which the immune system is suppressed by exposure to HIV [AIDS]

5. removal of a mediastinal organ [thymectomy]

6. malignant tumor of lymphoid tissue in the lymph nodes and spleen; Reed-Sternberg cells are in lymph nodes [Hodgkin lymphoma]

7. spleen, thymus, and tonsils [lymphoid organs]

8. swelling of tissues due to interstitial fluid accumulation [lymphedema]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms with the descriptions/definitions that follow.

readingPart.reading:
CD4 + T cellsKaposi sarcomaviral load test
ELISAopportunistic infectionswasting syndrome
HAARTprotease inhibitor
HIVreverse transcriptase inhibitor

questionContent.questionText:
1. malignant condition associated with AIDS (purplish skin nodules appear) [Kaposi sarcoma]

2. human immunodeficiency virus; the retrovirus that causes AIDS [HIV]

3. white blood cells that are destroyed by the AIDS virus [CD4 + T cells]

4. group of infectious diseases associated with AIDS 

[opportunistic infections]

5. measures the amount of HIV in blood 

[viral load test]

6. weight loss with decreased muscular strength, appetite, and mental activity [wasting syndrome]

7. drug used to treat AIDS by blocking an enzyme needed to make copies of HIV [reverse transcriptase inhibitor]

8. drug used to treat AIDS by blocking the production of an enzyme that creates new viral pieces for HIV [protease inhibitor]

9. use of combinations of drugs to treat AIDS 

[HAART (highly active antiretroviral therapy)]

10. test to detect anti-HIV antibodies 

[ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay)]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms or abbreviations related to AIDS with the descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. chronic, disabling diseases caused by abnormal production of antibodies to normal tissue: auto[immune] diseases
2. a hypersensitivity or allergic state with an inherited predisposition: a[topy]
3. a malignant tumor of lymph nodes; follicular and large cell are types of this disease: non[Hodgkin lymphoma/-Hodgkin lymphoma]
4. fluid that lies between cells throughout the body: inter[stitial] fluid
5. formation of lymphocytes or lymphoid tissue: lympho[poiesis]
6. chronic swelling of a part of the body due to collection of fluid between tissues secondary to obstruction of lymph vessels and nodes: lymph[edema]
7. an unusual or exaggerated allergic reaction to a foreign protein: ana[phylaxis] 
8. introduction of altered antigens to produce an immune response and protection from disease: vac[cination]
9. test that separates immunoglobulins: immuno[electrophoresis]
10. antibody used in immunotherapy; produced in a laboratory to attack antigens and destroy cells: mono[clonal] antibody

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms according to the definitions provided. Pay close attention to the proper spelling of each term.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Mr. Blake had been HIV-positive for 5 years before he developed [Pneumocystis pneumonia/thymoma/multiple myeloma] and was diagnosed with [AIDS/Hodgkin lymphoma/non-Hodgkin lymphoma].

2. Mary developed rhinitis, rhinorrhea, and red eyes every spring when pollen was prevalent. She consulted her doctor about her severe [allergies/hypersplenism/lymphadenitis].

3. Paul felt some marble-sized lumps in his left groin. His doctor told him that he had an infection in his foot and had developed secondary [inguinal/axillary/cervical] lymphadenopathy.

4. Mr. Jones was referred to a dermatologist and an oncologist when his primary physician noticed purple spots on his arms and legs. Because he had AIDS, his physician was concerned about the possibility of [Kaposi sarcoma/splenomegaly/thrombocytopenic purpura].

5. Fifteen-year-old Peter was allergic to peanuts. His allergy was so severe that he carried epinephrine with him at all times to prevent [anaphylaxis/adaptive immunity/immunosuppression] in case he came in contact with peanut butter at school.

6. When she was in her mid-20s, Rona was diagnosed with a lymph node malignancy known as [Hodgkin lymphoma/sarcoidosis/Kaposi sarcoma]. Because the disease was primarily in her chest, her [mediastinal/inguinal/axillary] lymph nodes were irradiated (radiation therapy), and she was cured. When she developed lung cancer in her mid-40s, her oncologist told her she had a/an [iatrogenic/hereditary/metastatic] radiation-induced secondary tumor.

7. Mary has suffered from hay fever, asthma, and chronic dermatitis ever since she was a young child. She has been particularly bothered by the severely pruritic (itching), erythematous (reddish) patches on her hands. Her dermatologist gave her topical steroids for her [atopic/toxic/opportunistic] dermatitis and told her to avoid soaps, cosmetics, and irritating chemicals.

8. Bernie noticed pain in his pelvis, spine, and ribs and was evaluated by his physician. Blood tests showed high levels of plasma cells and abnormal globulins. Increased numbers of plasma cells were revealed on [bone marrow biopsy/chest x-ray/stem cell transplantation]. Radiologic studies showed bone loss. The physician's diagnosis was multiple [myeloma/sclerosis/thymoma].

9. AIDS is caused by [human immunodeficiency virus/herpes simplex virus/monoclonal antibodies]. Lymphocytes called [CD4 + cells/suppressor cells/B cells] are destroyed, leading to [opportunistic infections/anaphylaxis/atopy].

10. Drugs used to treat AIDS are [protease inhibitors/immunosuppressants/interferons]. Other anti-AIDS drugs are [reverse transcriptase inhibitors/monoclonal antibodies/immunoglobulins].

instructions.instructions: Select the correct term(s) to complete each sentence.
